title: Cofactor Expansion in Linear Algebra
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how to expand a determinant along any row or column using cofactors.

problem.statementHtml: Given the matrix A = [[2, 1], [4, 3]], compute its determinant using cofactor expansion along the first row.
hints: Consider expanding along the first column instead

workedExample.problemHtml: Given A = [[2, 1], [4, 3]], compute its determinant using cofactor expansion along the first row.

steps.description: Find the minor of the top-left element
steps.explanation: The minor is the determinant of the submatrix obtained by removing the first row and column.
The cofactor is the minor multiplied by (-1) to the power of (row number + column number)

steps.description: Repeat steps 1-2 for the remaining elements
Sum up the products of the elements and their cofactors
steps.explanation: The final answer is the sum of the products

intuition: Cofactor expansion helps us break down a complex determinant into smaller, more manageable pieces.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Cofactor Expansion: Solving Determinants
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll apply cofactor expansion to find the determinant of a matrix.

problem.statementHtml:
Find the determinant of the matrix A:

\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\]
problem.solutionHtml:
To apply cofactor expansion, we'll choose a row or column and expand along it.

We'll start by expanding along the first row:

\[\begin{align*} \det(A) &= a_{11}(A_{22}-a_{12}a_{32})-a_{21}(A_{42}-a_{31}a_{41}) \\ &= (2)(4-1(3))-(3)(4-1(4)) \\ &= 6-9 = \boxed{-3} \end{align*}\]
